data.title: The Complete History Of Previous Winners In The UEFA Euro Cup
meta_keywords: Previous winners of the Euro Cup
data.meta_description: Europes elite competition held every 4 years for countries under the European Union and the past winners.
data.text:
Similar to the World Cup held every 4 years, the UEFA European Championship is also contested after every 4 years amongst the top national teams associated to Europe and UEFA.

Soviet Union and West Germany participated in the tournaments till the 1988 edition and prior to the disintegration of the Soviet Union in 1991. Thus we have a list of Champions from the past, starting from the 1960s when the tournament was known as the European Nations’ Cup final to the last edition held in Ukraine known as the UEFA Euro Cup 2012.

1. UEFA European Championship 1960

Winner – The Soviet Union

Runners up – Yugoslavia

Final Score – Soviet Union 2-1 Yugoslavia (After ET)

The first ever European final went to extra time after a 1-1 draw in the first 90 minutes. Viktor Ponedelnik scored a header to win it for the Soviet Union in the second half of extra time. The final was played at the Parc Des Princes, Paris.

2. UEFA European Championships 1964

Winner – Spain

Runners up – The Soviet Union

Final Score – Spain 2-1 Soviet Union

The Soviet Union was just six minutes away from defending the title after 4 years and after reaching the final in the 1964 edition. But Spain’s Marcelino scored the eventual winner after the first 90 minutes to break the deadlock on 1-1.

3. UEFA European Championships 1968

Winner – Italy

Runners up – Yugoslavia

Final Score – Italy 2-0 Yugoslavia

The final in this tournament finished 1-1 between the hosts Italy and Yugoslavia. Though the semi-final draw was decided after a toss, this one needed a re-match. The re-match ended 2-0 in Italy’s favor giving them their first European title.

4. UEFA European Championships 1972

Winner – West Germany

Runners up – Soviet Union

Final Score – West Germany 3-0 Yugoslavia

A brace from Gerd Muller and another goal from Herbert Wimmer demolished the Soviet Union side which featured in a European Cup final for the 3rd time. The performance of the German team was much superior and that reflected in the result.

5. UEFA European Championships 1976

Winner – Czechoslovakia

Runners up – West Germany

Final Score – Czechoslovakia 2-2 W. Germany (5-3 on penalties)

The most entertaining final since the inception of the European Championships, this one went to the nerves as the Germans equalized in the last minute to force the game to extra time. The extra time score remained 2-2 and eventually Czechoslovakia won it 5-3 on penalties. Uli Hoeneb was the German to miss in the shootouts.

6. UEFA European Championships 1980

Winner – West Germany

Runners up – Belgium

Final Score – W. Germany 2-1 Belgium

The third final for West Germany gave them their second title after two quick goals from Horst Hrubesch downplayed any advances from the young Belgium side in the final. Rene Vandereycken successfully converted a penalty for the Belgians but that wasn’t enough on the night.

7. UEFA European Championships 1984

Winner – France

Runners up – Spain

Final Score – France 2-0 Spain

France totally dominated the contest with Michel Platini scoring a brace and reaching a record breaking 9th goal. The 9th goal also gave France a 2-0 lead in the final and ultimately prized them with their first title.

8. UEFA European Championships 1988

Winner – Netherlands

Runners up – Soviet Union

Final Score – Netherlands 2-0 Soviet Union

This tournament saw veterans Soviet Union take on the Dutch but is remembered more for Marco Van Basten’s stunning volley to score the second for the Netherlands. The Dutch had their first winners medal in their first ever final.

9. UEFA European Championships 1992

Winner – Denmark

Runners up – Germany

Final Score – Denmark 2-0 Germany

The Danish side in this tournament eliminated the then defending champions Netherlands in the semi-finals and blanked the Germans in the final. The unified German team was looking too strong but a first half shot by John Jansen gave Denmark the lead and they extended it right before half time to win 2-0.

10. UEFA European Championships 1996

Winner – Germany

Runner up – Czech Republic

Final Score – Germany 2-1 Czech Republic (After extra time – golden goal)

Germany pushed aside their loss in the finals four years ago to take the tie into extra time. Then German midfielder Olivier Bierhoff scored the first golden goal of the European Championship’s history giving Germany the title.

11. UEFA European Championships 2000

Winner – France

Runners up – Italy

Final Score – France 2-1 Italy (Extra time- golden goal)

France came after winning the World Cup in 1998 and was looking at their second major European trophy in as many years. The French side was lucky to slide past a late equalizer to bring the game to 1-1 after normal time.

David Trezeguet scored the golden goal winner 13 minutes into the extra time to secure the trophy for Les Blues.

12. UEFA European Championships 2004

Winner – Greece

Runner up – Portugal

Final Score – Greece 1-0 Portugal

Greece reached the final after just two previous entries into the competition and played hosts Portugal who were clear favorites to win the title. But to everyone’s disapproval, a shocking 1-0 win gave the title to minnows Greece.

Angelos Chariestas scored the only goal of the game for the Greeks.

13. UEFA European Championships 2008

Winner – Spain

Runners up – Germany

Final Score – Spain 1-0 Germany

The Spanish side with the likes of Casillas, Ramos, Puyol, Senna, Xavi, Iniesta and Torres went unbeaten in the whole tournament and faced Germany in the final.

A 33rd minute strike from Fernando Torres was enough to win the trophy in 2008. The final was held in Vienna, Austria.

14. UEFA European Championships 2012

Winner – Spain

Runners up – Italy

Final Score – Spain 4-0 Italy

Spain successfully defended their European crown in Ukraine as they thrashed Italy 4-0 in the final. This was the biggest winning margin in a European Cup final much to Italy’s embarrassment.

The score was already 2-0 in the first half when Thiago Motta’s injury brought the Italians to 10 men. 2 more goals from David Villa and Juan Mata made it 4-0 and Spain became the only country to defend a Euro Cup title successfully.
